item.description:
The purpose of this game is to travel around the Czech countryside and visit 12 different castles, learn about their history and learn to manage given resources.
 The goal is to get all cards and castles (12 in total, from each of the three colors for 4 pieces) - each card with a picture of another castle.
 A player can end the game, even if the card gets at least 10 castles, while he may miss a maximum of two colors of 1.
 Thus, the game ends but only in the case where this is for itself to be favorable. In the event that the game fails to get at least 10 different cards, the game ends when all the pictures of castles have been played.
 The player, who has the most money at end wins, even if he does not have all the cards and castles.

---

item.description:
Ever wondered how life is at the police station? Definitely do not expect a large bureaucracy, you'd better get ready diaphragm! As a target for criminal bullet as a torture device laughter ...
 To play, you will need:
Two six-sided dice
 Pencil and paper for counting points
 Matches or coins to progress cards and inserted them into action
 Try out what it's like to be a true guardian of the law. Learn to use service weapons to fight criminals, starting with hooligans and thieves, through repulsive deviants, to the rough and dangerous mafia assassins. You collect royalty, grant and fulfill orders. And the best is awarded the title police president!

Each player starts with four random cards. Then you prepare pencil and paper which is for tracking current status of policemen level; very level means more cards during turn. At each turn, players have a total of three events. Usually, they will all revolve around playing cards. The most important thing in the entire game cards are interventions and arrest that brings gamers the most points to policemen. To do this you need set of card and support of a partner or have necessary equipment (body armor, torch etc.). 
 Includes: 108 playing cards, rules, ranks, police summary

 Ke hÅ™e budete potÅ™ebovat:

 Vyzkoušíte si, jaké to je, být opravdovým stráÅ¾cem zákona. NauÄíte se pouÅ¾ívat sluÅ¾ební zbranÄ›, bojovat s kriminálními Å¾ivly, poÄínaje chuligány a zlodÄ›jíÄky, pÅ™es odpudivé devianty, aÅ¾ po drsné mafiány a nebezpeÄné vrahy. Budete sbírat hodnosti, udílet i plnit rozkazy. A ten nejlepší získá titul polecejní prezident!
 Obsahuje: 108 herních karet, pravidla, hodnosti, policejní pÅ™ehled

A party-style card game where players use their creativity to finish prompts by building off of starter words. These are judged by another player who selects his/her favorite. The player who submitted this is then awarded a point.

The game begins with one player being chosen as the judge. A blue prompt card and an orange starter card are pulled from the deck and read out loud to everyone.

The remaining players finish the prompt by writing a phrase that incorporates at least one of the starter words. These phrases are known as wordners, and may make starter words plural, change their tense, and add other words to them.

The players submit their wordners on a piece of paper to the player on the judge's left, who reads them out loud. The judge selects his/her favorite, and the creator of this is awarded a point represented by the round's blue card.

Now, the player to the judge's left becomes the judge and a new round begins. The first player to collect 5 blue cards wins!

"Reservoir Dogs" The board game

Six professional criminals are hired by Joe Cabot and his son Nice Guy Eddie for a job. Not know each other and remain anonymous, hidden under color names: Mr. Orange, Mr. White, Mr. Pink, Mr. Blonde, Mr. Brown and Mr. Blue. Prepare thoroughly robbery diamond store, but police shows up unexpectedly at the time of making a slaughter robbery resulting in the deaths of several police officers, and employees. All suspect that there is a traitor infiltrated in the group.

Thieves who manage to survive and get to the warehouse with the diamonds will win the game, but there is an undercover agent who will try to sabotage them. Police will also further complicated the getaway. Besides the briefcase with diamonds can change hands and perhaps one of the robbers take not to share with others

" The memory game that gets you moving"

Tune up both your reflexes and memory by waving your hand in loops that can sense your motions. Seven game modes available for 1-4 players, including a mode that allows you to create your own music.

- Repeat the Beat
- Rhythm and Flow
- Versus Mode
- Reflex master
- Musicology
- Freestyle DJ
- Music studio

(Battery included!)

Players compete against each other or the game by repeating sounds or combinations of sounds played by the game. Moving your hand over a sensor in the loops triggers a correct or incorrect response from the game. Sometimes you must use both hands to trigger a correct response. The game demands both memory ability to replay the right sequence of sounds as well as dexterity in moving your hands to the correct location(s). The non-game modes teach music scales and you can create songs with the correct hand placement in the open loops or "LOOPZ".

item.description:
In Tricky Wildlife, each of the players is a wildlife manager who's trying to keep many different animal species in his wildlife park, while also preserving the food chain of predators and prey and helping endangered species.

The food chain of animals has top predators who eat the lower predators, who in turn eat the next species down the "animal pyramid", who in turn eats the lowest prey – for example: Sharks eat Penguins, Penguins eat Fish, Fish eat Shrimp. Missing a prey animal means that the higher animal type starves, which gives you penalty points as a wildlife manager. Thus, you want to maintain all species in your wildlife park, especially the rarest species as they give you prestige points.

In each of the eight game years (i.e., rounds), you can add 1 or 2 animal groups to your park; each group first consists of 1-4 animals of one species. When you attract them to your park, these are young animals. They can grow old and die naturally after five years, but to do this they need enough prey to feed on during their lifetime. Otherwise they starve. At the same time, higher predators in the food chain can eat these animals.

An animal's age is shown by its location on your lifetime track, which uses four sticks to divide the track into five sections (i.e., years). After each year, you shift your rightmost stick to the leftmost side, which ages all of your animals by one year.

When you don't have all four different species, you gain one penalty point per missing species (and higher level animals may starve). If you have the most (or second-most) of an animal which was rare before, you score 1-2 prestige points. After year eight, you add the number of your animal groups to your prestige point total to calculate your final score.

The challenge in Tricky Wildlife is to balance your desire for prestige points with the need to preserve your complete food chain.

item.description:
Take your place alongside Jules Verne's most famous characters – or try to anyway! Captain Nemo is ready to designate a second officer on the Nautilus, and you need to prove your knowledge in five key areas that are dear to the Captain.

Over the six rounds of Nautilus, you must take divers to the bottom of five fields of knowledge: Science, Exploration, Navigation, Engineering and War. In each round, five Domain cards are placed face up on the game board, then players take five Diver cards in hand, with values ranging from 1 to 14. At the end of the round, the Diver values played on both sides of the Nautilus determine how the Domain cards are allocated. Special cards grant special abilities to each player.

At the end of the game whoever has scored the most points in a field claims that field – and whoever wins a majority of the five fields wins!

item.description:
In Mad Barrington's Gyre players compete to accumulate the shares worth the most bottle caps by the end of the game. "Why bottle caps?" Because in the post-apocalyptic future of flying castles, giant robber baron cockroaches and mutated broccoli.... bottle caps are the coin of the realm.

Each player starts with a identical set of cards and can play, buy or sell cards each turn that improve their deck's purchasing power or allow them to impact the value of shares (Guns, Ammo, Food, Water, Meds & Pennies) directly or indirectly through rumour cards or affecting the number of stock value cards in play.

Shares are bought and banked separately from each player's main deck but the stock value cards that determine the value of the shares are bought and sold from a common pool that is manipulated by the players throughout the game.

As well, each player has a character card that gives them a distinct bonus in the game ranging from Humbles Wuggles-Roach's ability to buy Ammo shares at a reduced rate to Lord Fat Pockets ' improved starting bottle caps and Mad Barrington's ability to buy rumour cards on the cheap.

From the game box:

"The Game of Rhyme and Reason.
In this hilarious cross between Chinese whispers and drawing charades you start by inventing a rhyme... Anything from "A Rat on a Mat"... to "A Fish on a Dish"... or even "Plaice in Space" The next player then has to draw your rhyme! Moving clockwise, the initial rhyme is hidden and the drawing interpreted as a new rhyme... ... and that is where the fun begins! With everyone drawing and guessing at the same time it's a crazy, frantic, befuddled muddle of a game!"

At the end of a round points are scored for drawing a phrase correctly and for recognising the original rhyme. Several rounds are played and the winner is the first person to score 20 points.
Contents: game pad, pencils, score pad, rules

A simple trivia game played on a map of the German State of Schleswig-Holstein.

A long track winds around the State, starting in Hamburg and ending on the Isle of Sylt. Movement is decided by a die. There are four categories of questions:
A = General knowledge
K = Culture
W = Economic
P = Politics and History
Obviously, all the 500 questions in the game have some connection to Schleswig Holstein.

There is an interesting shortcut that may be taken where no questions are asked. Instead you roll the die and if you get a number from 1 to 5, you move two spaces. But if you roll a 6, you must go back 15 spaces.

First to reach the end (Ziel) wins.

On a little bit of extra trivia, the board shows clearly that the Eastern neighbour to Schleswig-Holstein is, in fact, the DDR (East Germany). As the game was published in 1989 and the wall came down that year, then this might be the last non-historical game to feature the DDR as a neighbouring country.

Crazy Cakes is a race game where players try to be the first to stack their 12 triangular wooden pieces on top of each other to represent 12 layers of a cake. Be the first to match the recipe card and win that card.

The challenge is that each piece is 3 sided, and each player has two of each flavor but the sides are different. EX: Each player has two strawberry pieces - 1 piece will have two vanilla sides while the other has two chocolate sides, use the wrong side of that piece and the puzzle (cake) can't be made. This is when the frantic fun begins!

It's the "Game of High-Stacking fun."

Stavropol Bashni is a stacking game from the Checkers family. It features shared pieces. As in all Checkers games, the aim of the game is to leave the opponent without a legal move. It is played on a traditional 8x8 Checkers board with stones that are suitable for Bashni, i.e. stackable and with kings being turned men or pieces of a different color, as most traditional Russian sets are.

The rules follow Bashni. In short, when a man or king is captured, it is not taken from the board, but put under the piece which captures the men. This way, stacks are formed. Generally, to topmost of piece of a stack decides which player the stack belongs to, how the stack moves, it is the piece that is promoted on reaching a back rank, and it is the piece that is captured. If the topmost piece of a stack is captured and the next piece at the top belongs to the opponent, the stack switches allegiance and belongs to the opponent then.

The difference to Bashni is that pieyes are shared - as in Stavropol Checkers. A player may move stacks owned by the opponent, too, according to the rules for the topmost piece. The exact winning condition is therefor: a player loses when it is his turn and the stacks belonging to him have no legal move.

Online play:

 igGameCenter

item.description:
Stage Chaser is a bicycle race themed board game. It allows players to compete against each other in any of the world’s greatest bike races; including ones they’ve just made up.

The board is made up of interchangeable terrain mats which, when fitted together, form the profile of a stage. The stage can be flat, hilly or mountainous – whatever the players choose.

Each player is in a charge of star rider. They move their rider along the board by playing action cards, whose values vary according to the kind of terrain they are played on. The majority of the action cards show other riders in the race (team mates of the star riders) who can be slipstreamed, but there are also ‘attack’ and ‘block!’ cards. Players need energy tokens to move forward when they play attack cards and these are fought over during the race. Block! cards allow players to sabotage the moves of their competitors.

The aim of the game is to cross the finish line first. If just one stage is played, the winner of the stage is the winner of the game. If more than one stage is played, the winner of the game is the player with the best overall score when all the stage results have been added together.

This two player game is packed in an small box and offers two variants.
1. Each player has four pawns which are placed in the corners of the board, specifically the corners that present one field (dot). The object of the game is to reach the corner of the opponent with all four pawns (like Halma). Jumping pawns, both own and adversary's, is allowed.
2. The second is an Asalto-like game. One of the players has only one pawn, the other four, The object of the game is to encircle the one pawn. The four pawn player may move his pawns only in de forward direction. The one pawn player can move each desired direction, Jumping is not allowed.

A car race game that includes elements of Memory.

Each player is given a set of 20 cards. Your set is shuffled and layed face down in two rows of 10 cards. This will be your 'track'.

Every turn, a player turns over two cards. If they match, his car can move on to one of them if one of the two cards is 'next in line' on the track. Thus, the first thing to do is to get a matched card on one of the two start cards. Having acheived that, you want to get a card face up in row 2, and so on. If you do not find a match,your turn is over. If you do find one, you can turn over two more cards and keep going until you fail to expose a matching pair.

The first player to reach row 10 on his track, wins.

Welcome True Believers! Ka-pow is an action-packed card game of super-heroic mayhem. Create a heroic identity, form a superhero team and then battle the worlds super-villains and save the earth.

Each player takes on the role of a superhero, fighting for truth and justice as part of a superhero team made up of the other player’s superheroes. Your team must foil the diabolical plots of a series of nefarious super-villains and in doing so the superheroes will receive victory points based on their contribution towards defeating each super-villain. At the end of the game the superhero with the most victory points is the winner.

As you will see, the superheroes must work together to defeat each super-villain, otherwise the villain will win and all of the players will lose! However, once all of the super-villains are defeated, only one of the superheroes can win the game. Collecting victory points calls for playing the right card at the right time, so you will need to think very carefully about which cards to use each round and how to use your superpowers in order to score as many points as possible. On the other hand, being too selfish in the use of your cards and superpowers may result in a super-villain being able to carry out their diabolical plot, and if that happens everyone will lose the game. It’s a dreadful dilemma make no mistake – but then nobody said being a superhero was going to be easy!

Compete over 3-5 story arcs to be the most heroic Superhero and earn the adulation of the public.

The land of Nippon is riven by civil war and the leaders of the different factions have a number of secret missions they need carried out. As master of one of the four great Ninja clans you must train your warriors so they are ready to carry out the missions offered. But beware, if you take too long one of your rival clans may undertake a mission before you and steal the rich reward offered for carrying it out.

In Shinobi: Way of the Ninja, you control a ninja clan and must perform different missions in order to obtain wealth and win the game. The missions you are called on to carry out are represented by three Mission cards that will tell you what you need to do (the task), where the mission is to be carried out (the location), and what problems may arise that will hinder you in the missions execution (complications). Each of these things requires one or more Skill cards from your hand to overcome. For example, if the mission required the use of unarmed combat you would need to play that Skill card in order to carry it out.

Once you have collected all of the Skill cards you need you may carry out a mission and reap the rewards for your clan. Unfortunately you will rarely have the right cards in your hand to perform a mission straight away. Instead you will need to store cards from your hand for future use by placing cards face-down from your hand into one of two dojos you control. Storing cards in this way represents you training the ninjas in your clan to perform a mission.

Keeping track of the cards placed in each dojo is challenging as you are not normally allowed to examine the cards once they are placed. You must use your powers of concentration and memory to remember which cards you have placed so that you can use them when you are ready to carry out a mission. Although this is difficult at first, you will find that your mental abilities quickly sharpen and that you will become increasingly skilled at the game. This is as it should be: being the master of a ninja clan requires great mental fortitude, and Shinobi: Way of the Ninja will test it to the utmost. However, if you get completely stuck, you can always visit the sensei who will (at a cost) allow you to examine the cards you have placed.

You receive a reward for completing each mission in the form of gold. The harder a mission the more gold you will receive, but the more cards you will need to play to carry the mission out. At the end of the game the player who has amassed the largest fortune wins.

Merchant of Venus uses many elements that come together to form a very interesting game. Players take on the roles of space traders who move their ships through interconnected systems discovering new alien worlds to trade with. As players start to make money delivering commodities in a unique supply-and-demand system, their earnings can be used to purchase better ships and equipment (shields, lasers, engines, etc...) and construct their own spaceports (which speed up trading) and factories (which create better commodities). Variations included in the rulebook allow for interplayer combat. The player who first acquires enough total value ($1000, $2000, $3000, $4000) in cash and port/factory deeds takes the day.

For the 2012 edition of Merchant of Venus from Fantasy Flight Games, the company promises that this revision "remains true to its magnificently campy core while updating the map and game components and expanding game play in surprising ways that will cause even the most hardcore fan to celebrate." That said, the player count has been lowered from six (in the Avalon Hill edition) to four, with the four races in the game being Human, Whynom, Qossuth, and Eeepeeep.

item.description:
A dexterity game in which two players are each equipped with a small plastic frying pan and a squishy plastic "egg". The opponents simultaneously toss their egg to the other person, who attempts to catch it in their frying pan. This repeats until someone drops their egg and loses.

There is also a solo version in which one person sees how many times they can toss the egg up in the air and catch it.

name.value: 1836: Short Lines in the West Riding

item.description:
1836 is a railway operations and share trading board game in the 18xx series. Set in a 10 x 10 mile area of the West Riding area of England that had a staggering number of very small railway companies called "short lines", each of which competed very aggressively across duplicative routes.

The core features of the game:

- Highly dynamic track – There are a relatively high number of named locations that can be laid / upgraded in a variety of competitive ways to ensure that the map develops differently each game.

- Evolving trains – Each train type evolves as it is bought; e.g. there are 2* 2+1, 2* 2+2 then 1* 2X (think of it as a mini diesel that can count two cities and infinite towns). The 2+1 is rusted by the first type of four (4+2), 2+2 by the second (4+3) and so on.

- Staged Minor Companies – Minors are available throughout the game, 18 are shuffled and 4 are available in each of phases 2, 3 and 4 (all 12 available privates are visible from the start). Minors convey a benefit (control over a hex, cheaper track etc) and about half are railway companies that can be absorbed along with a "free" train that can be run immediately.

- Loans with Variable Interest Rate – When a Minor is absorbed by a Major Company it inherits the Minor's liabilities. Loans suppress stock price making stock jumps easier but the interest rate increases as loans are taken, so a balance must be found.

name.value: Time: A Game of Chance for Many Players

item.description:
The time theme is very loosely pasted onto this game. The clocks used on the board and the cards could have just as easily been card denominations. This is a simple game of match.

A dealer/banker is assigned. Each player is dealt five cards face up. The dealer then deals one card face down on each of the 12 clocks on the board. In the first round of play the dealer turns up one of the twelve cards at a time. If a player has a matching card in one of his/her upturned five, then the player has to pay in the amount of chips/points indicated at that point on the board in large red letters. If the player has two matching cards, the player must pay double and so on. If the overturned card matches the time on the board at that spot, TIME is called and all payments are doubled. In this round all payments are made to the pot. After all twelve cards are overturned they are returned to the deck, reshuffled, and a fresh twelve are distributed to the twelve clock positions face down. The players keep their original five cards.

In the second round, as each of the twelve cards are overturned, payments are made to the players following the same rules as in round one. The rules do not explain the end of the game scenario. Nor do they explain if the rounds continue to alternate put/take. It is also unclear how many chips the players start with. It is suggested that the white chips equal 1, the yellow chips 2, the red chips 5 and the blue chips 10.

Theme:
You and your friends are heroes standing before the vanguard of an invading army. Use your array of very large, sometimes ridiculous, weapons to try to defeat the vanguard.

Goal of the game:
Players try to keep a grid of enemies from growing too large, all while trying to outscore the other players in the end. If the enemy army gets too large, everyone loses!

Gameplay:
Players draw a weapon from the Weapon deck. Weapons have two stats: Damage done and how many times the weapon can be swung. They use this weapon to deal damage to the enemy formation, starting with the front line. Players can keep hitting the same enemy, or proceed to an adjacent enemy. Players keep any enemies they kill. The player can cash in the enemies they've killed to draw from the Epic deck. Epic attacks function the same as a weapon, but are far more powerful.

item.description:
A racing game with a theme of environmental protection. The first player to collect an eco medal on all six continents and to reach his/her starting location with 1.000 eco dollars wins the game.

Players travel around the world to take part in environmental protection activities and by doing so, win eco medals. Open cards present the actions that have to be taken. There is one card fewer than there are players, so there is competition for actions.
Movement on the board is determined by dice. One can choose to use only one dice and earn 200 dollars, or use two dice and earn no money, or one can pay 500 dollars to use the plane. When a player reaches the target destination, they earn an eco medal of this continent and the card is removed from the game and replaced with a new one. If a player lands on the same space as another, he/she can take away money or a medal from that player.

The game ends when one player has earned a medal of each continent and reaches his/her home town with at least 1.000 eco dollars in his/her pocket.

Space Battle is a power struggle between you and your opponents for control of the galaxy. This is a "take that" card game with silly cards.

There are two similar versions of the game in the box. 
Everyone starts with some ship cards randomly drawn from the ship deck. Each ship gives you access to use particular kinds of weapon cards that you draw from a shared deck. These cards like "red laser" and "drones" are used to wear down other ships. Some cards destroy ships in ways outside of weaponry.

When you destroy another ship you get the printed Victory Points for it. If all your ships are destroyed you go to the deck to see if you are lucky enough to get a card that gives you another ship to stay in the game, otherwise you are eliminated from play, but victory (in one version of the game is based on points).

name.value: Die Lieben Sieben: Heute steigt die Party!

item.description:
Childrens dexterity game.

From the box:
The Friendly Seven want to celebrate a big party in the mansion Siebenklein. They cleaned up the house already, only the balloon decoration is missing. Four of the friendly Seven blow up the ballons and the other three hang them up.
Would you like to help the Friendly Seven to decorate the house?
A game ofskills to develop hand-eye coordination.

The game is a dexterity game for younger children.
The board is in 3 segments, with coloured spaces, at the far end a goal is constructed looking like the front of a house, with an open doorway. Players take it in turns to flick or shove a "puck", down the long gameboard attempting to stop on spaces of a particular colour, landing on a colour gets the player a token to add to their playerboard.
When all 6 different colours are collected, then the player may attempt to shoot the puck through the doorway of the house at the far end of the board to win.

A simple racing game for two players. Movement is determined by a six-sided die.

The game consists of a board (showing a 37-space racing track), 4 player tokens and a die. Both players try to get their soapbox derby racer (i.e. one of their two player tokens) to the finish line first. Players take turns rolling the die. The player's first token (the racer) is moved according to the result of the die roll. If the racer lands on a stop space, the player has to send his/her mechanic (= the second token) the following turns. Only when the mechanic has reached the racer, the racer can move on. The mechanic stays on the stop space until the racer lands on another stop space.

The player whose racer reaches the finish line first wins the game.

A children's game in which judging length and shape by touch is the central element.

Game idea: A long time ago Schnuffel, the dog, and his friends hid many bones in the garden. Now they want to dig them up again but not any old bones, it has to be specific ones. The bone has to be the right shape and size. And the dogs are chasing away each other too!

Aim of the game: To find the correct wooden bone by touch as quickly as possible in order to collect the most bone cards.

How it is played: The board shows a circular path consisting of single-colour spaces and multi-coloured dog-house spaces. Arrows next to the spaces show the direction in which the dogs move. Each player has a dog-shaped player piece. A colour die determines movement. The active player puts his/her dog on the next empty space of that colour. If he/she lands on a dog-house space, he/she is allowed to search for bones. This means that he/she puts his/her hand into the bag with the wooden bones and tries to find the bone that is shown on the top bone card. While he/she is trying to identify the correct bone by touch, the other players continue taking turns rolling the die and moving their dogs. As soon as the active player thinks he/she has found the correct bone, he/she shouts "Stop!" and the other players stop rolling. The chosen bone is compared to the one on the card. If they match, the active player gets to keep the card. The wooden bone is returned to the bag. Then the active player starts searching for the next bone. His/her turn ends as soon as either one of the other players lands on a dog-house space, or he/she chooses the wrong bone.

End of game: The game ends when all the bone cards have been used up. The player with the most cards wins the game.

Game components:
- game board
- 4 dog-shaped wooden player pieces
- 9 wooden bones (different lengths, round piece on one end, or on both, or none)
- 18 bone cards (showing the different lengths and shapes)
- color die
- cloth bag

Yellow Jersey is a cycling race for 2-4 players. Starting in Paris, you move your team of three cyclists around France through a series of race stages by choosing (a variable number of) movement tokens from your stack, with the token being numbered 1-6. Each round the player holding the Yellow Jersey moves first. You will need to plan how to move your bikes so that you retain maximum movement and take advantage of opportunities to slipstream. Crashes, uphill slopes, and the outside lane will slow you down, whereas downhill slopes and the inside lane may work in your favor.

The race can be conducted either way around the circuit and the first player to get one cyclist back to Paris wins. (The game includes a team winning variant.)

An educational game aimed at teaching the rules of conduct on ski pistes ("Pistenregeln").

The game combines roll-and-move elements with trivia game elements. The board shows four different skiing areas. Players move their player tokens up the ski lift according to their die roll results. Once they've reached the top, they can ski downhill (again using die roll results), but first they have to answer a question connected with skiing, such as "What is forbidden on a chair lift?", "What is important when overtaking other skiers?" etc. Apart from questions on the rules of conduct, there are general skiing trivia questions like "Where was skiing invented?" or "When did the first skiing race in Central Europe take place?"
The first player to complete four downhill races wins the game.

In Å½ivot v ÄŒesku ("Life in the Czech Republic"), players start with a bit of free time, some volunteer work, and experience in primary school. During the course of the game, they can study at different schools, try a range of jobs, buy a house, start a family, and (alas) suffer from negative phenomena, such as an arrest.

Å½ivot v ÄŒesku, which is tailored to the Bohemian Czech mentality and environment, features a new unique gaming system that gives players a lot of latitude in what's possible within the game.

A simple, luck-based racing game for children.

The game consists of one island tile, 4 wooden turtles, 43 cards and one six-sided number die.

The island tile is the target space that all the turtles (= wooden player pieces) want to reach as fast as possible. The cards, which show either one of several sea creatures or a smaller island, are used to create a path towards the target island tile. They are placed face down.
Players take turns rolling the die. The die roll determines how far the player may move his/her turtle. The card it lands on is turned over and depending on the type of card, the turtle is moved several spaces forwards or backwards.

The player whose turtle is first to reach the main island wins the game.

name.value: Armored Knights North Africa: Operation Venezia

item.description:
This game is the follow on and expansion to Armored Knights North Afrika - Operation Crusader. The game does not include and map and therefore you need to have Crusader to play it.

The Commonwealth and Axis sides have taken a breather after the successful advance by the Afrika Korps in February to the Gazala Line. They have built up considerable forces and by the end of May are ready for major combat operations. Rommel gets his attack off first and makes for the fairly predictable plan of maneuvering down under the Gazala Line and then up toward the coast to cut off the Commonwealth infantry manning the Gazala Line boxes. Rommel was caught a bit by surprise in not understanding how powerful the new Grant tank was and how they would affect the performance of his own panzers. After the initial advance the Axis forces were cornered in the 'Cauldron' and spent a few days making the position impregnable, clearing away the 150th Brigade box, and then springing out to destroy the majority of the Commonwealth armor and move to the coast and then on to Tobruk.

These German Panzer forces, and to some extent the British Armor Brigades, are the strongest you will ever see in concentrated form. You will enjoy maneuvering and fighting this battle with the possibility of never having the same outcomes as the Armored Knights game system provides a variable strength and die roll modifier table that never lets a player know exactly how well his troops will fight an engagement.

link.value: Armored Knights North Africa: Operation Crusader

item.description:
City of Gears is a unique steampunk game of exploration, area control, worker placement, and engine building. From your incredible Factory, you must race to claim ownership over the magnificent ruins of an abandoned clockwork metropolis. Each game plays in under an hour, and because only nine of the city tiles (from dozens available) are randomly chosen and placed each game, no two games ever play the same.

Each turn, you roll a number of production dice and activate City Tiles, then you move your automaton workers and perform a variety of actions (such as drawing and placing gears to reactivate areas of the city, sabotaging opponents, and activating unique steam powers) as determined by your resources. Along the way, you will develop your Factory with special powers which set it apart and provide you with powerful bonuses.

As the city is revealed and its abilities are discovered, players must concoct plans to accrue prestige and hinder opponents so that once Opening Day arrives, they will emerge victorious! Do you have what it takes to set the City of Gears in motion?

link.value: City of Gears: Juggernaut Mini Expansion
City of Gears: JUSTICE and MIGHT
City of Gears: Shadows in the Steam

item.description:
Incredible Courage at Elchingen is the battle where Marshall Ney defeated the Austrian General Reisch just north of the Danube River, just before the surrender at Ulm. Ney must move 2 of his divisions over the river first and then fight a larger enemy force. The Austrians helped the French immensely by keeping themselves in their defensive positions.

The game system has a variable strength system that provides for an endless amount of replayability. This game provides an excellent introduction to the Incredible Courage game system as the forces involved are fairly small, one French Corps vs One Austrian Corps. This game has some improvements over the Incredible Courage at Austerlitz series with a better organized rulebook and Level of Order markers that better portray what level the unit is currently at.

Play proceeds based on a set of initiative die rolls and Leadership values for Division and Corps Commanders. Players then choose to either fire or move. Play alternates between the players until all divisional and corps forces have had the opportunity to move or fire. Firing is accomplished unit by unit. Units may perform assault before moving on to other Divisions. Units are modeled as Infantry Companies (150 men), with Battaion substitute counters, Cavalry Squadrons (100 mounted soldiers), and Artillery Sections (2-3 guns). Units take losses in Levels of Order, starting at 5 for regular troops and 6 for Elite troops, and when they reach 0 they are eliminated.

Players must use the tactics of the day to put the right forces in the right place at the right time to ensure the success of the mission. Putting infantry, cavalry, and artillery together will enhance your chances of success.

The hands are the second brain.

With Chop Chop, you can develop this "second brain" by training yourself to grab items as quickly as you can with chopsticks. Fill your plate as quickly as you can to exercise your hand, fill your belly and – most important of all – rid yourself of the plate card fro mthe current round. Let's see who can collect the most fruit and fill all of their plates first!

CCULELE Champion is an action and memory game, with everyone participating at the same time to follow the poses presented to them. One by one, more poses will be presented and the challenge for you is to remember them all so that you can take actions of your own. Are you ready to challenge others to become the champion?

Players have special marbles and the slide on the 3' table. The try to have their pieces stop in the 3-2-1 zone for scoring. The directions state that players may play going the same direction or in opposite directions (unlike similar shuffle board type games).

item.description:
"Lingon, lådvin & långkalsonger" is an entertaining game where you win or loose points based on how typically swedish you behave.

The game contains 300 questions about everything from Eurovision song contest and croqs shoes to the swedish sausage "falukorv".

The rules state some examples on how to play the game but leaves a lot to the players to decide. But the main course of the game is that a question is given about how you would act/think in a certain situation (there are also some traditional quiz questions). The players then say or write down their answers. After this points are added/subtracted according to the backside of the card. The winner is the player with the most points at the end. This player is a so called "Svensson", a typical swede.

item.description:
In Copyright, players need to reproduce a pattern as quickly as possible using the transparent image sheets that they have in hand. Each sheet is a 3x3 grid that has a circle, a square, and a plus in three of its nine squares.

At the start of a round, one player takes four image sheets at random, then stacks them together to form a model for that round. Players receive ten sheets at random, then try to reproduce the model by flipping the sheets and stacking them any way they like; the sheets do not have to overlap perfectly, but a player will lose points for any non-perfect overlaps. How does a player indicate which squares in his stack are to be considered the solution? Through the use of a 3x3 grid that has a thick black outline; each player has one of these in addition to the ten sheets.

As soon as a player recreates the model, the round ends. Each player scores one point for each square in the model that she reproduced in her image; whoever ended the round receives one bonus point, scoring 10 points (instead of nine). All players then lose one point for each row and column that "sticks out" from her 3x3 black-bordered grid. Players then shuffle the sheets and start a new round.

When a player's score totals 20 or more points, the game ends and this player wins.

name.value: Pz8 Two Pages Wargaming Rules Collection

item.description:
A collection of miniature wargaming rules that are only 2 pages (A4) long: the Pz8 rules are intended for a small table, ideally with "micro" models, play fast (from 30' to 1 hour) and are solo friendly.

Classic miniature wargaming mechanics are used, in the simplest possible way, but trying to keep a minimum degree of realism and allowing historical tactics. All rules use D6 for resolving combat. Some of the rules, like the WW2 and Modern land, use rulers for movement and weapons ranges, while others use a grid system, like the WW2 and Modern aerial (hexes) the WW1(squares) and the WW2 naval (large areas). Representational scales vary from 1 base of miniatures = 1 Battalion or 1 Platoon, to 1 model = 1 aircraft or ship, again depending on the rules set.

Available as a free .pdf the Pz8 Wargaming Rules Collection includes:

- Pz8 WW2 rules 
- Pz8 1950-75 rules 
- Pz8 1975-2010 rules 
- Pz8 Sci-Fi rules 
- Pz8 WW2 Divisional rules 
- Pz8 1939-41 Naval rules
- Pz8 WW2 Coastal rules
- Pz8 Space rules
- Pz8 WW1 Divisional rules
- Pz8 1935-65 & WW1 Aerial rules
- Pz8 1965-75 Aerial rules
- Pz8 Colonial Wargame rules
- Pz8 Fantasy Wargame rules
- Legio VIII Ancient / Medieval Wargame rules

Aim of the game: Each of the players tries to create the L-shaped sign of the Flying Crane with his/her pieces. Their opponent tries to block him/her.

Each player has 9 pieces, 7 normal pieces and two blocking pieces in a different colour. Each player tries to get 4 of his/her pieces into an L-shaped position. The active player can either move one of his/her normal pieces (one space horizontally or vertically, and only onto empty spaces) or move one of their blocking pieces (up to two spaces horizontally or vertically, or one space diagonally).

The player who manages to create the sign of the Flying Crane wins the game.

A roll-and-move game that aims at teaching children how to safely get to school (traffic rules).

The game consists of a game board, 4 player pieces, 16 cards, 60 plastic chips, a number die and a colour die. The board shows a path to school. The aim of the game is decided by the players - either being first to reach school or winning the most chips.
Players take turns rolling the number die and move their piece according to the die roll. If you land on a space with a circle next to it, you earn a chip. Reaching a stop sign means you have to stop. On your next turn, you roll the colour die and can move on if you roll green. Landing on a space with an exclamation mark means you've put yourself in danger (board shows a dangerous situation) and you lose a chip.
There is also a variant that uses cards: Before crossing a road, you have to answer a road safety question printed on one of the cards.

Castles is a game for 2-4 players. Each player will try to build the biggest and superb castle. The player with most victory points wins.
Each player receive a building ground sheet with 4x7 building spaces, a gate token, a castle token and 32 wall tokens in one color.
The wall tokens from all player will be mixed face down in the middle of the table. This will be called stone pit.
In each round every player draw two wall token from the stone pit for his castle. Each correctly placed wall token will count one victory point.

In Castles werden die Spieler zu ideenreichen Baumeistern, welche aus dem vorhandenen, aber leider nicht immer passenden Material einen prächtigen (und möglichst vollständigen) Palast erbauen sollen. Dabei helfen Vorstellungskraft,
Improvisationstalent und architektonische Schadenfreude.

item.description:
The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

Several other rules are proposed including soloplay rules.

Similar to La Boîte à Quiz.

Questions about WWE and wrestling.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

Questions about Asterix.

name.value: La boîte à questions insolites: édition de luxe

item.description:
Similar to La Boîte à Quiz.

Topics are nations and customs, words and phrases, inventions and discoveries, history and geography etc. A thick booklet contains extensive responses.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

name.value: La Boîte à énigmes spéciale police scientifique

item.description:
Another version of the La Scatola degli Enigmi. 
Twenty-five murder mysteries in three levels of difficulty. The game master becomes aware of the full puzzle with its solution, and then reads the beginning of the investigation to the players. These can then ask questions that will be answered by yes or no. The gamemaster can help players by giving up three indices.

name.value: La Boîte à énigmes pas si scientifiques que ça

item.description:
Another version of the La Scatola degli Enigmi. This time the riddles refer to areas very familiar, and we wonder why we never asked these questions before. The answers, in turn, are often a good sense appalling.

Players or teams compete in puzzle-solving (sometimes timed, sometimes not) in order to score points in different categories. The first team (or player) to score a point in 4 of the 6 categories wins the game.

Every turn, the current player/team draws a card and hands it to the Dealer, a non-competitive figure that reads it aloud and then manages the competition between the people trying to solve the riddle.

Based on the La Boîte à Quiz the game is more suitable for young audiences. The box contains everything needed to play except an hourglass, paper and pencil.

Topics are animals, plants, the earth, the human body, space, history and science. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme. Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

Junior version with fantasy theme

Players or teams compete in puzzle-solving (sometimes timed, sometimes not) in order to score points in different categories. The first team (or player) to score a point in 4 of the 6 categories wins the game.

Every turn, the current player/team draws a card and hands it to the Dealer, a non-competitive figure that reads it aloud and then manages the competition between the people trying to solve the riddle.

Similar to La Boîte à Quiz with 150 general knowledge questions.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

160 cards featuring 300 questions with six categories ("Letters", "Science", "History", "Geography", "Arts "and" Sports "). A book with a general introduction, the rules and the detailed responses of the tests.

Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme. Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

Several other rules are proposed including soloplay rules.

THON is a fast-paced tactical miniatures wargame for two or more players pitting the Starlight defending Thonians against the ruthless Sons of Ord. Will you defend the Warfront or raze it to ash?

Players play the role of the LAR, their faction's supreme leader, and control an elite force led by a Commander or Overlord.

THON uses a D6 system called SCOMA - Shooting, Combat, Movement, Armor.

Hungarian trivia game. Random draw a letter to different categories (country, city, famous man) each round. The players try to write things with beginning the suitable letters. What somebody else did not write is worth one point. The player collect the most points is the winner.

item.description:
A roll-and-move game based on the cartoon series "The Country Mouse and the City Mouse Adventures".
The aim of this cooperative children's game is to lead all 4 pawns through the story of the stolen diamond and to solve the case together with Emily, Alexander and Sherlock Mouse before Notail Nogoodnik, the thief, is seen five times.

The board shows a track consisting of lots of coloured spaces and pictures from the cartoon series. There are four pawns. Players take turns rolling the colour die. The active player moves a pawn of his/her choice to the next space of the colour on the die roll (all players can move all pawns). If a pawn lands on a yellow space, one of the twenty, randomly distributed face-down tiles has to be turned over. If it shows a picture from the board, the pawn is moved to the corresponding space. If the tile shows Notail Nogoodnik, it stays face-up and the player's turn is over.
To get a pawn to the finish line, the spaces has to be reached exactly.

If all four player pawns reach the finish line, all players win together. If five tiles showing Notail Nogoodnik are turned over, they all lose together.

cHTeMeLe the first HTML5 certified boardgame, the nearly collaborative and nearly educational game about HTML language

The aim of this new board game is fairly easy : create THE HTML page with the cards you have to hand... the game is played from 2 to 5 players, each player endorses a web browser (Firefox, Safari, Chrome, Opera, Explorer). Lay out your tag cards, and respect the web standards and rules and accumulate points. Play the "events" cards to step in each others browser's way (crash, bug, etc.) or help you in the race for building the web page.

item.description:
Can you become the biggest hipster? Collect cappuccinos, canvas bags, and LPs while avoiding mainstream items to prove your Cred.

Each player is uniquely assigned two traits (from the pool of Academic, Activist, Elitist, or Grungeling) and is dealt a hand of eight items. An item has a trait - one of the above four or the detestable Mainstream. In turn order, each player selects a card from that hand to play. A player can play the card on himself, which will give him positive score if it matches one of his traits and negative score otherwise. If the player already has a negative scoring card, he can play a negative scoring card on another player. After each player has chosen played one card, everyone rotates hands to the next player.

Each trait has one card of each of ten point values. If a card is played on a player who already has a card of that value, the new one covers and replaces the old card. At the end of the game, each player totals their score and adds or subtracts points for a run of at least two cards of the same color - scoring or losing a point for every card in the run, depending on whether that color is positive or negative for the player. Highest total score wins!

In Game Over, each player is a small barbarian looking for his princess, but she's locked away in a dungeon — represented by a 5x5 square of face-down cards — and to free her you need to locate the key. To visit a room, place your character on a card, then reveal it to see what you encounter; perhaps something unfortunate like Blorks, the exit (which you can hope to use later), or perhaps even the key...

Game Over is based on the comics of the same name illustrated by Midam.

item.description:
A post-apocalyptic vehicular combat game for 2 to 8 players. It uses the quick setup and rapid play of a card game and combines it with the tactile and visual strategy and excitement of a miniatures game. Nothing needs to be written down during play, it's a great way to introduce younger card game players to the world of miniature gaming. Gameplay is normally 15-30 minutes and most players will understand the rules after their first game. How many wargames can fit all their rules on a single sheet of paper?

ScrapIron is 100% Zombie Free!

Players each use a miniature vehicle as their playing piece. The game was designed around the popular Hot Wheels and Matchbox lines but can be easily adapted to any size vehicle.

Players choose equipment from an Equipment Deck prior to the start of the game.

Action cards are chosen during the planning phase and placed face down. Order if play is determined randomly and actions are then carried out in that order.

When damage is dealt, cards of the Damage Deck are given to the target player. Damage cards will either assign Structural Damage to the vehicle, 10 points and the car is out of the game, or cause special effects. These effects could cause the car to spin out and face a random direction, cause the player to lose Action cards or otherwise harm the target.

When the last car remains that player is the winner! That did not take long, why not play again?

Kavelspel is a four player game. Each player has 9 tiles of the same colour. At the beginning of the game the tiles are placed on squares of corresponding colour: f.i. blue tiles on blue squares. Each group of 9 squares (in the corners) is rimmed by a line in one of the four colours, blue, green, red or yellow.
The object of the game is to move the tiles to the corner rimmed by the colour corresponding with the colour of the players tiles.
In each move the players may move one of their tiles a number of squares (1 or more) in a horizontal or vertical direction.
From the moment a player has reached the target square with one of his tiles, he is allowed to remove one of the tiles of the opponents from his target area, thus making room for his own tiles.
When a target area is filled with eight of the required tiles of the same colour, there is one square unoccupied. The only one that may fill that square at this stage of the game is the player that needs to complete the number of nine tiles in the target area. That would be his final move. However he is only allowed to move that final piece one square per turn.

UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

 
 
 The information that BGG has on this item indicates that [_BLÄNK] is a non-authorized version of Cards Against Humanity. According to the designers of Cards Against Humanity, the producers of [_BLÄNK] do not have license to produce this game, thus it is set apart from the official entry of Cards Against Humanity.

 


A card game which involves a judge choosing a black question or fill-in-the-blank card. Each player holds a hand of ten cards at the beginning of each round, and each player contributes card(s) to the "[_BLÄNK]-Master" anonymously. The [_BLÄNK]-Master determines which card(s) are funniest in the context of the question or fill-in-the-blank card.

The player who submitted the chosen card(s) is given the question card to represent a "Siegkarte" (Win Card).

In addition, there are a few extra rules. First, some question cards are "Pick 2" or "Pick 3" cards, which require each participant to submit cards in sequence to complete their answer. Second, a gambling component also exists. If a question is played which a player believes they have two possible winning answers for, they may pay in a "Siegkarte" to play a single second answer. If the player who gambled wins, they retain the wagered point, but if they lose, the player who contributed the winning answer takes both points.
After each round, the role of the [_BLÄNK]-Master rotates around the table, and play continues until everyone decides to stop.

Gameplay is identical to "Cards Against Humanity", but was translated to German.

item.description:
"Sip and Strip is an exciting game designed for swinging adults of all ages" -- so says the instruction booklet that comes from the game.

This is a Frank Bresee game, similar to nearly everything else he made, it includes a Monopoly-like board, drinks, and this time stripping. The game includes a routine board, "sip" cards and "strip" cards (standing in for Community Chest and Chance). The game can be played by two to six players or even more if you want to play with couples as teams.

The roll of the dice moves your pieces around the board and you are required to do what the squares tell you to do. Mostly this involves taking sips of a beverage, sometimes taking a Sip or Strip card. Some of the Sip cards direct personal action like "take a sip and kiss any player" and other cards require all participants to take an action, usually involving another sip of a beverage.

Each complete round of the board includes more Sip cards and more Strip cards requiring you to remove a piece of clothing. The game proceeds until the sips catch up with you (which is the point of Bresee's more notorious game "Pass Out") or until everyone has removed all articles of clothing. The game suggests the last player to remove the last article of clothing is the winner, but local rules may suggest other winners may be declared.

The length of the game depends greatly on potency of beverages, how many articles of clothes players are wearing, and natural distractions that arise from game situations. Unless all participants are really committed, the games can easily break up from prudishness or embarrassment.

Cibola is a head-to-head race to find the Seven Cities of Gold. In Cibola, players seek to collect and place the five required keys to unlock each of the seven gold statues. Players can use various tools and cunning to hinder their opponent.

There are also Silver (wild) statues for players to unlock. However, these will cause players to decrease their hand limit by one card, making their journey all that much harder.

The game ends once one of the two players has unlocked all seven statues.

This game consists of decks of cards each with five words and their definitions on them. The Blarney Master - chosen by the roll of the die - selects a card, then chooses one of the words by speaking it. The 3-minute timer is begun and the players have that long to write down their definition of the word.

Scoring is determined the players voting for the "best definition" and points are awarded to the player with the most votes and the player with the best definition and the Blarney Master if no one votes for the correct definition. The one with the most points gets a green Blarney stone to indicate such. That ends a round; then the Blarney Master position passes to the next player.

On certain cards, one of the words has no meaning so is simply "Blarney" and the Master must make up a plausible definition.

The game ends after 10 rounds; the winner being the player with the most Blarney stones.

name.value: DAM IT the River Conquest Game

item.description:
DAM IT the River Conquest Game

Great strategy board game DAM IT takes place on a grand river system. With your crew of skilled beavers you will be charged with the task of damming rivers that legends say can’t be dammed. To make matters worse your enemies on the other team will be fighting for the same goal. A good balance of military strategy and well placed dams will be the key to your success. To master this game you will have to use strategy, team work, and just a little bit of luck. During game play you and your team will be faced with tough choices, but don’t be afraid to get wet just make sure you can swim. DAM IT Two Sides… As the game begins, six beaver tribes march onto the battlefield. The Red, Green, and Yellow tribes form the Honored Beaver Alliance, fighting for peace, justice, and wood. The tribes of Blue, Black, and Purple unite to form the Midnight Warriors, fighting to protect the homeland of their ancestors. One Battle… There is an uneasy calm as both teams face each other from across the river. Each tribe raises its flag as the architects discuss their building strategy. The kings stand nobly to ensure victory, and out of the silence comes the command of a warrior: “Charge!” One River. There can be only one victor, the team with the will to Dam It.

The game Dam It is a team game that can be played by 2 players, 4 players or 6 players. Games involving 4 or 6 players are always played in teams. There are 4 ways to win. 
(1)_eliminate the kings of opposing players 
(2)_capture the dens of opposing players 
(3)_dam the end of the main channel river and control it for 6 consecutive allied turns; and 
(4)_control 50 or more worker beavers.

Game time: approximately 1 hour

Note: It’s important to spend 10-15 minutes, or so reading the rules carefully. The more time you spend learning the rules, the more fluid and enjoyable the game will be.

The five types of beavers 
1. Worker beavers 
2. Flag beaver 
3. Warrior beaver 
4. Architect beaver 
5. King beaver

In Dam It, each beaver serves a different purpose and has unique skills. All +1s and +2s are numbers added to die rolls during the combat phase. The combat abilities of these beavers are summarized on the reference sheet under “Combat Statistics”.

1. Worker beavers comprise the bulk of your team. These beavers are easily persuaded. These beavers can collect wood and may be led into battle. The red and blue chips are used to represent the worker beavers of each team. 
2. A Flag beaver is an elite beaver that has been trained to repel attacks. To represent this, he is given a +2 while defending. This is the beaver holding a flag. 
3. A Warrior beaver is an elite beaver that has been trained in the art of war. To represent this he is given a +2 while attacking. This is the beaver with a Mohawk or with a Viking helmet (for early editions the warrior is also represented by: muscles, snorkel, eye patch, and hair). 
4. An Architect beaver is an elite beaver that has studied his/her whole life to become the leader in dam construction. This beaver must be present to construct dams. If the Architect beaver is eliminated, that player can not build dams. This is the beaver holding a book. 
5. A King beaver is an elite beaver that is cautious and effective in his war tactics. To represent this he is given a +1 while attacking and a +1 while defending. If this beaver is eliminated from the game, then all other elite beavers from that player are also eliminated, and that player’s turn is skipped for the rest of the game. This beaver is the one with a crown on his head.

An solitaire game placing the player in the role of a downed aircrew member behind enemy lines. Utilizes the paragraph-driven RANGER game system. A team of active duty military pilots helped during the development of this game. It can also be linked with RANGER with one player leading a patrol to locate and recover the other player.

name.value: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
Boss Monster: Costruisci il tuo dungeon
Boss Monster: gra karciana o budowaniu podziemi
Boss Monster: Le jeu de cartes de création de donjon
Boss Monster: Master of the Dungeon

item.description:
Inspired by a love of classic video games, Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game pits 2-4 players in a competition to build the ultimate side-scrolling dungeon. Players compete to lure and destroy hapless adventurers, racing to outbid one another to see who can build the most enticing, treasure-filled dungeon. The goal of Boss Monster is to be the first Boss to amass ten Souls, which are gained when a Hero is lured and defeated — but a player can lose if his Boss takes five Wounds from Heroes who survive his dungeon.

Playing Boss Monster requires you to juggle two competing priorities: the need to lure Heroes at a faster rate than your opponents, and the need to kill those Heroes before they reach your Boss. Players can build one room per turn, each with its own damage and treasure value. More attractive rooms tend to deal less damage, so a Boss who is too greedy can become inundated with deadly Heroes.

Players interact with each other by building rooms and playing Spells. Because different Heroes seek different treasure types, and rooms are built simultaneously (played face down, then revealed), this means that every "build phase" is a bidding war. Spells are instant-speed effects that can give players advantages or disrupt opponents.

As a standalone card game with 155 cards, Boss Monster contains everything that 2-4 players need to play.

item.description:
From the publisher's website:
YOLO is the addicting card game where the lowest score wins! Players are dealt four cards face down. Throughout the round you'll be swapping cards in and out trying to memorize which card is which number. The YOLO cards are the highest and lowest cards in the deck and can push your total into the stratosphere or save you! If you think your set of four cards is lower than everyone else's, then it is time to GO FOR IT! Why not? YOU ONLY LIVE ONCE!

New York, millions of zombies, and you. Fight alone or with friends, and smash a way through
hordes of zombies. Throw your dice as if your life depends on iit, and find support and supplies in the city that now never sleeps. Clear zombies out of critical locations. Use your best tactics, throw the dice and pray for a little bit of luck. Find weapons, tools and fellow survivors. Help each other out of perilous situations. Be ready to free New York from the virus.

Either win the game or be overrun and turned into a rotting zombie.
Three games in one package!
Play alone, with a partner or against each other; all the time fighting an endless stream of the living dead.

1 or 2 player, solitaire, co-operative or against eacht other.
A new kind of dice game with a strong theme.
Luck and tactic is needed here!

A Looney Pyramids game in the spirit of Ricochet Robots: an 8x8 board has 9 stationary towers and 3 mobile robots. Each turn, a randomly chosen robot must move onto a randomly chosen tower. Towers and the map edge and other robots block movement (but goal tower does not block movement).

Player simultaneously try to find the smallest sequence of moves to achieve the goal, and the lowest bidder who successfully moves the specified robot to the specified goal earns a point.

3 stashes of pyramids (in 3 different colors), an 8x8 board, and an optional 30-second timer are the only equipment needed.

item.description:
A game for 3 to 6 year olds, helping them with their counting skills.

There are 24 monkey cards with a maths sum on them and 24 cards with different numbers of bananas on them. Three games are described but all really relate to recognising the correct banana tile to go with the correct sum (E.g. Monkey card says 3 + 2 so the tile with 5 bananas is the correct match.

The games include a Memory game (instead of matching like tiles you match the sum to the correct banana tile, played just like Memory.

This is fantasy board game for 2 – 4 players who wander through underground corridors and rooms, fight with monsters and collect some objects. 
Mechanic is standard -I go you go 
The aim of this game is to find three magic objects: golden crown, diamond dagger and magic ring. 
The winner is the one who leaves the underground with at least two of three magic objects.
The game probably inspired by Talisman

A domino variant that uses dice as well as the domino cards. Of course, the cards can be used for a standard game of dominoes except that they feature an image on half the card and letters on the other half. You match a correct initial letter to an image (M next to Moon for example or vice versa). The game is housed in an attractive tin box.

Other games are included that bring in to play the special dice. One dice is what wargamers would call a Fire Die. It has 1 x two on it, 2 x two on it and 3 times two.The other die has letters on each face, four letters or five letters. And sometimes they use the wooden Wizard figure that is included with the game.

In game 1,2,3 - Magic! each player gets a hand of five cards and 12 cards are laid out in a circle, like a clock. However, a clock with 24 divisions because the cards are laid end-on thus forming a chequered track, picture, letter, picture, and so on. The Wizard is placed on one of them. The number die is used in this game. In your turn, you roll the die and advance the Wizard that number of spaces. When he has moved and lands on a picture space, the player looks at the picture and sees if he can think of a word that describes the picture. If he can then he must check his hand and see if the word he wants to use begins with one of the letters in his hand. If he does have such a card he can return that card to the box. If the Wizard lands on a letter space the reverse applies. The player looks to see if he has a picture card that begins with the letter. The first to use up all their cards, wins.

In Enchanting Fairy, the letter die is used. Each gets a hand of cards. The Wizard is placed in the centre of the table comfortably in reach of all the players. The die is roilled and all the players look to see if they have a picture beginning with one of the letters face-up on the die. If they do think they have the right answer, they can grab for the Wizard. Whoever gets it first (several players might grab for it at the same time), announces his answer and, if correct, returns his card to the box. If he is wrong he must draw another card from the shuffled deck.The first to use all their cards, wins.

Interesting additional fact. HABA add the usual disclaimer that the game is not suitable for under threes as some components could be swallowed. Nothing unusual in that except they write it in 40 languages!!

Congratulations! You've just found a suitcase full of money on your doorstep! Wait – why would someone leave you a bunch of money? Hmm, what's this note inside the case? "Welcome to the bomb game. The rules are simple. Use the materials inside this case to kill the other nine people in the enclosed photo. Only then do you get to keep this money." You dig deeper into the case and find a bunch of electronics and a photo that depicts ten people – including you. You don't know the other people in the photo, but you know they're now gunning for you...

In Boom, you need to wipe out the other players, while keeping your distance from them so that they don't find out where you are and retaliate!

The ant queen has decided to move! So now the two top ant engineers have come to the new land, and while the nest engineering commenced smoothly, the two engineers are secretly competing to prove themselves more competent than the other ant country's first engineer!

In Ant Nest, you'll play one of the two engineers charged with designing a new nest to house the country.

Who's the hungriest Zombie among your friends? Find out with this outrageous, fast-paced party game. This game is based on the popular "I Have" card game. The winner is the first player to run out of cards. Players race each other to drop Zombie, Werewolf, Ghost, Spider, and other horror creature cards into the Darkness Pit.

Players are dealt cards with "I Ate" side up and these cards will be laid out in front of themselves, same side up. The first player reads his/her "I Ate" card. Example: "I Ate a Werewolf". After reading the "I Ate" statement, he/she flips that card over and reads the "Who Ate" side of the card. Example: "I ate a Werewolf. Who ate a Zombie?" All players then race to respond to the "Who Ate" question if they have that specific card. To respond to a "Who Ate" guestion, a player says, "I Ate a...Who Ate a...?" and places his/her card "Who Ate" side up in the darkness pit (card pile). Play continues as stated above until a player gets rid of all of his/her cards to the darkness pit.

Based on the world famous novel Don Quixote de la Mancha written by Miguel de Cervantes, in this game players take the roles of Don Quixote and his fellow knights Amadís de Gaula and Tirant lo Blanc or a group of monsters opposed to them. Don Quixote will travel around the board, which represents the spanish central region of La Mancha, trying to reach victory by following and completing a route through a series of tiles that represent the different adventures that the real character has to face in the book. In the meanwhile, the other knights should protect Don Quixote from the attacks of the monsters, who will try to hurt, imprison and finally kill him to win the game.

name.value: Viaje al Centro de la Tierra

item.description: The game is based on the novel "Journey to the Center of the Earth" written by Joules Verne. Players take the roles of up to four adventurers who will race through the 3D board trying to be the first ones to achieve the center of the Earth and therefore win the game. To do this, they will face a hard ascension of the ancient Sneffels volcano, a descent into its dark and misterious insides and finally a nightmarish counter-clock run against the lava flowing in the center of the Earth. During the journey they might face dangerous secondary adventures but also find precious treasures. But beware! Only those adventurers to equip themselves with the right object for each stage of the journey will be able to successfully race against the others.

item.description:
In the game Demon Busters, the players take the role of one of five soulkeepers. Through their magical powers they mend the holes in the fabric that separate the world of men from the realms of evil beings.

The five soulkeepers agree, over the time of one year, who ever got the most accomplishments in battle, will become the head of the five soulkeepers. Each month, a demon of a thousand years, equipped with supernatural powers, leads the armies of darkness through the holes between the worlds. Now, the soulkeepers have to compete with each other. Through the use of superior magical powers they entrap and capture the demons. Once a demon is captured, the soulkeeper who entrapped him can make use of his special powers to capture even more demons.

At the end of the game, who fixed the most holes in the fabrics of the world had the highest contribution to saving our world and is the winner of the contest!

item.description:
As lobby and campaign spending soars to record highs, Congressional approval ratings plummet to all-time lows. Explore the influence of money on Congress while playing this educational card game.

There are two kinds of cards in the Politics and Corruption deck: bill cards representing legislation of the 112th Congress, and capital cards that are used to solicit votes and champion bills. Players take turns playing capital cards on bills until the draw pile is exhausted. Bills pass with a simple majority, meaning more than half of the votes on a bill are in support. Bills may either occupy the center of the table or be placed in front of a player who has chosen to champion them. Championed bills earns their champion more points when passed, but costs that player a point when blocked. Players also earn points by passing bills that are favored by their party, and by ending the game with lots of cards left in their hand. The player with the most points at the end of a game is the winner.

The players have all arrived at the company as new employees, full of ambition and eager to work hard in order to dominate the company and rise up from a nobody to a somebody thanks to the admiration of others.

But to rise like a phoenix and transform into a dragon at the company, as everyone wants to do in Workaholic Liver War, you'll need to gain the cooperation of your colleagues while taking good advantage of your personal skills and random events inside the company walls. Experience in-fighting, develop a fantastic career, suffer from a burst liver due to all the stress and pressure, and ideally in the end get everyone else to bow to you respectfully...

Whoever in Darkminded Merchants is most conscienceless, most unscrupulous will make the most money and win the game? Using "fresh" tofu as substitutes in your dishes? Putting unsavory sauces in the shrimp? Adding plasticizers to the drinks? If you can be this darkminded, you might just win the game.

In this war between businessmen, you must see through the black-hearted tactics of others while also being able to reap the maximum benefits possible from a time of crisis to dominate the industry and prove that your heart is the blackest of all.
